posts.com: So how does Pokerus work in this? I know it can only effect eggs and only ones that you manually put in the daycare, but beyond that I am not sure what to do and if I can fuck it up somehow if I don't watch out what I am doing and lock out a large amount of my team from getting it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52961388
the recipient has to match one of the types of the infected eggs being hatched

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52961388
You can't mess it up in any way. Pokerus spreads between eggs in the daycare that share a typing. Newly infected eggs cannot immediately spread it until they've hatched. "Contagious" and "Resistant" are misnomers: Contagious just means it has pokerus with less than 50 EVs accumulated while Resistant means you passed that point and will see diminishing returns on EV gain. Both spread it the same.

>>53003428
Something to ponder: The artwork at the top is older than the artwork on the bottom. The top was drawn for Red/Green, and the bottom for Japanese Blue. But the Blue artwork was drawn while the anime was already in development, and the anime used the Red/Green artwork as reference. The popularity of the anime basically set the style of Pokemon from then on.

But imagine if the Blue artwork was used as reference instead. Pokemon would probably have a more dynamic art style now.

That's the thing, there's no guarantee when the actual LOOK of these evolutions came to be. It shows my point clearly when one-off evolutions are added in direct sequence, as there is a clear pattern of their introduction. We lack a sense of timescale, but for them to be all added like this seems more of a code-sided implementation, that is to say initiating their records and potentially adding simple stuff like stats. This doesn't make any sense if all of these pokemon were completed conceptually / designed and sprites. Vs the Caterpie line, which was added directly in sequence - no matter how you look at it, the family was already linked, and the context of the surrounding 25+ indices does NOT indicate they simply said "yeah add a set of new Pokemon that's a 3-stage bug with early game stats". It indicates, like with Beedrill, that they had a clear vision of what Caterpie would be. And the indices indicate that this family was at least added directly after Venomoth in the development cycle, regardless of time elapsed.
To see this data, and conclude that these two strong candidates for an easy sprite swap even in modern games were NOT at least on the same docket and compared is VERY foolish.

>>52987909
This is unironically what I do. If you ask the AI what the best way to input information, it will give it to you. For example, I write more novel style so a lot of the "bots writing only dialogue" thing is a turn off for me. I can usually try to swipe around it, but the AI told me that the examples you put in their profile are what they tend to go off of, so if I make them more novelized, they're capable of doing that more regularly.
They also told me the long description sets up most of their base personality, so definitely think very carefully how you fill that part in. If you notice your AI acting in a way you don't like, try adjusting that out more or adding more flare.

Gardevoir has spent 8 continuous hours of processing data on a computer.
The sounds of the computer humming with a whirring fan and fluorescent lights buzzing give voice to this scene, punctuated only the the sounds of her typing. Finally done for the day, she shuts down the computer, folds her glasses with a click and sets them there on the keyboard for later. She sighs, rubbing her eyes, and leaves for the night. It’s a short journey back, just a quick ride with her Charjabug scooter and she’s home. Setting her Pikachu-yellow helmet aside when she gets home, she enters to meet her loved in there as he’s cooking dinner for the both of them.
Without speaking, they embrace to the noise of clothes ruffling against each other and food sizzling in the pan.
She’s home.

There's been a few Pokemon that have disappointed me over the years, but none have made me feel the visceral fucking bitterness that pic related has

The moment I saw this thing in the leaks, I wanted to add it to my team, and how could I not? An Ice/Fighting yeti crab sounds like the coolest shit ever. Now keep in mind, all I spoiled myself on from the leaks is the Pokemon themselves. I had no idea about anything else

So I get Sun on release day, and of course the moment I can catch a Crabrawler I do. And it does pretty well early on, and I'm thinking "Oh man this is gonna rock when it evolves"

I'd imagine that other cat pokemon's personalities are based on other cat behaviors. Purrloin and Liepard, for example, are based on how mischievous cats can get; I'll admit that Purrloin especially amuses me, because my current cat can and will steal miscellaneous small objects if I leave them on a table, and then run off and play with them. Sometimes they turn up again, but other times I'm not so lucky.

I think that if pokemon were real, all cat pokemon would act more or less similar to real cats. It's just that Pokemon only ever have those tiny pokedex blurbs to go on, so it doesn't have much space to fully flesh out their personalities aside from one or two traits.

posts.name: Anonymous.
posts.com:
>>52994615
>Apparently weakness advantage
Doesn't matter if your team is strong and fast enough
>all my old sync pairs are worthless now since team building is now based on themes or something.
Team Building is based on buffing your most powerful DPS as fast as possible. This includes crits, terrains, zones. and weather, as well as debuffing your opponents' defenses including type rebuffs. Most units are "worthless" if compared to the most broken units that are out in the game, but since the majority of stages can be beaten without broken units barring certain EBs and the highest LG win streaks, "old" sync pairs can stull find their place from time to time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52994615
A weather/terrain/wish seems to be the latest meta trend that everyone does, but for starter, a buffs/debuffs are more important to stay your team alive so have sync pairs that can at least raise stats and crits. Also check Area Details for opponents because DeNa always plays own rules especially Extreme Battle Event.

>>53002577
Which type do you have less good pairs for, Rock or Ghost? That should really be helpful in deciding which one to get, as it's hard to say for sure without context. I'd probably advise for Korrina, since SS Diantha could cover your Rock needs.

Emmet can be a devastating Rock striker considering he maxes all his offensive stats by himself and has both single target and AOE moves. He does require sandstorm setup to max out his effectiveness though so you'll need setters like his bro, Anni or Lodge Raihan, or Bertha, hell Acerola would probably do. Also consider that both of his moves have below-average accuracy, and considering he's gauge heavy missing can hurt. He does gain Piercing Gaze with his grid but only at 3/5.

SS Korrina buffs all allies' crits and buffs herself quite nicely too, making her great for double DPS. Her ability to steal stats three times is highly valuable against buff-reliant opponents, especially since it helps her get her sync multiplier. She can hit deceptively hard even with her 2 gauge moves, since Spectral Thief activates damage multipliers for two of her passives at once. Most importantly she has exposed tummy She's not a necessity if you have good ghost pairs like Anni Lillie or SSR Cynthia, but it definitely doesn't hurt to have her.

>>53002138
I think the fighting over the spotlight or Ash getting pushed into the background is a bit of an overstatement. PM19 really only feels lopsided in the final stretch, once the M8 begins and Goh's character essentially takes a backseat to watch the matches and support/cheer for Ash. Earlier on in the series, things feel fine - the first two Alolan episodes, for example. One gives Ash a chance to reunite with his Alolan family while Goh meets them for the first time, and the second has Ash/Goh working as a team to win a competition. Both have a good balance. Goh helping Ash with Gengar's Gmax form and Ash supporting Goh during the PM missions felt like a healthy display of friendship. There are other instances too where they worked together to solve problems, like when something would go wrong in the park or when a train was in danger because of a G-max Snorlax. Having two protagonists could work, and did to an extent, but it suffered because of a lack of planning and PM19 attempting to juggle too many ideas. The series does come up short and it's frustrating because of how good it could have been, but I'm still happy that we got it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think its problems stem from the fact that they outsourced it. Not that outsourcing the games is inherently bad. Quite the contrary, I would be excited to see what other, better developers could do with the franchise.

But they didn't give it to a better developer. There can be no risk of showing Pokémon fans how much better the franchise can really be beyond GF's capabilities.

So they gave it to the phone app developers who made Home and kept them on a tight leash, not allowing them to deviate too greatly from the original games or even include the Platinum content.

Compound this with the buggy, incomplete releases you get from the 'ship now, patch into serviceable product later' attitudes of the modern games industry, and you get the shoddy releases we received.

These games could have redeemed some of the weaker titles produced during an uncertain and experimental era for Pokémon. Instead we got 'member berries and the bare minimum.

>>52993478
The only thing about BDSP that was good was the underground, except within the same breath they turned secret bases into trophy cases in the name of muh faithful.

I could make a whole laundry list of reasons as I have before in threads like these, but for a majority of the problems, it boils down to being faithful in ways that keep poor design choices (that platinum fixed for a reason) but changed things that were good even in DP, again, like secret bases. Things like the art style also falls into this category in some ways. While I understand art style is subjective, DPPt were never chibi due to artistic choice, it was hardware limitation. Why transition between chibi and non-chibi otherwise? The next stage should have been what the original vision was trying to be despite its limitations. The in-battle art style is the same piss ugly Home style, too.

Reused animations from SwSh, butchered mechanics like Amie and Followers, an unchanged 1:1 map but with new 360 movement leaving you bumping and snagging on edges often, hilariously and notoriously buggy, the Home delays due to coding errors, 1:1 event distribution to those from 15 years ago that continues to leave late players out except it now includes the Platinum outfit with it, to no one's surprise no BF, Contests is now diet Osu!, cut Pokedex despite reusing Home's rendering and leaving out Sylveon in the process while also adding one whole new ribbon for no reason (fuck ribbon master Sylveons I guess!), you only get access to retro sounds in the post game and despite that the music audio is worse than if you just plugged headphones into a DS and listened to the music that way, forced Exp. All in a game not designed for it, and so on.

All of THAT, while at the same time, the other remakes have at least tried to bring something fresh to the table- even LGPE was more enjoyable. Simply put, this game was intentionally roadkill for LA's sake.

>Do not understand the hate for this game
That's why.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52996823
I mean, I think it is just speculation since I specifically don't have any direct confirmation. There may or may not be confirmation out there, though. But, based on design choices throughout the series, context paints a general picture. Games like XD, Colosseum, and PBR being fully 3D with no chibi whatsoever due to being on the superior console of the time while the GameBoy and DS games remained 2D. That said, it isn't hard to argue that gen 6 was merely a stepping stone as it evolved into what the baseline art style is now. Believing otherwise also does not mean generations before 6 didn't have limitations, either.

It makes the most sense to me, and even in the event that I'm just talking out of my ass, BDSP still looks ugly as sin. Link's Awakening did the chibi toy style much better, but they still had less than a year to pull something like that off anyway. It was set up to fail, one way or another.

Twinkle, the clown girl! Where she comes from, things work a little differently:
1- Gym leaders do not have pokémon types. Instead, they focus on "strategies" and different ways of having Pokémon battles. Twinkle's style is "fun" and "gimmicky". She battles to laugh and make her challengers have fun as well. Her unconventional strategies are not good competitively, but they surely are fun to look at and surprise you when they actually work.
2- Legendary pokémon are only used by the Pokémon League and the gym leaders. They do not exist in the wild and you will only see them in gym leader teams. Twinkle, in particular, gets a funky Mew whose only moves are transform, imprison and block.

"When you are with Pokémon, the fun never ends! That's my motto. Every Pokémon battle should be fun for us and our Pokémon, don't you agree? Let's have our Pokémon play together now!"

posts.com:
>>53000200
First game: Sapphire, but I had been into the franchise since episode 3 of the anime first aired on Cartoon Network. I didn't know there were video games for years, I just collected the cards and watched the TV show.

Favorite game: If romhacks and mods are on the table, then Rising Ruby. If only official games are allowed, then my favorite mainline game is Legends Arceus and my favorite overall game is Colosseum.

Favorite memory: Cosplaying as Joe from Battle Revolution and hosting a Gen IV tournament at my college campus. Omega Ruby & Alpha Sapphire were right around the corner at the time but a lot of people owned SoulSilver or Diamond or what have you, so we were able to get a decent event going.

First genuine shiny: Geodude encountered in Emerald's Magma Hideout, nicknamed Roquelle and eventually became a Lv100 Graveler. I don't even remember if I still have that cartridge, I honestly think I might have sold it at a yard sale after I started emulating.

Current Pokémon activities: Studying the decomp of Pokémon Red and jotting down ideas for a rom hack. I'd really like to have it done by Pokémon Day but who knows.

>>52966834
Some studios become so used to drawing certain things that they don't even realize they're veering away from the ref sheet. This is why some directors will provide a fuckton of direction to whoever they're outsourcing too. For example Koreans are notorious for drawing ridiculously exaggerated tears. If you ever see a scene in anime where a character is crying and the tears are comically big without intentionally being a literal stream like the "uohhh" emote it's a pretty safe bet that the animation for that scene was outsourced to a Korean studio.

>>52985048
>>52988537
The multiple abilities/innates is something with a lot of potential, but I just do not think the way Exceeded implemented it is good.
It's just egregiously awful that so many abilities have additional effects added to them. What the fuck? It's a system built around multiple abilities. If you want multiple effects, you should put them in different abilities to mix and match instead of trying to shove it into a single ability.
I hope the Voyager hack does multiple abilities better. Are there any other hacks implementing multiple abilities?
Anyways, some of my ideas for multiple ability systems:
>separate abilities into innate and learned
>innate abilities can't be changed, reinforcing the pokemon species' identity and playstyle
>learned abilities are either earned through level up from a specific pool in a manner similar to moves, or through special conditions in a manner similar to special evolutions
>learned abilities can be passed down through breeding, allowing for new synergies with abilities not normally learned
>don't allow for a free for all ability fest, as it weakens the reinforcement of a pokemon species' identity and playstyle, as well as enable lazy and broken combos.

>>52991405
>>52991401
If Tyranitar can have any 3 abilities from a pool of 10 that just makes guessing which ability combo your foe's using exponentially harder unless there is literally only one good option.

I love this Innate system. Unironically the best shit I've seen in any hack in decades. Though I do wish RNG was removed from the Innates. Also can "When this Pokemon makes contact with the enemy" and "When the enemy makes contact with this Pokemon" abilities trigger from either type of Contact? A Goodra hitting a foe should apply the Gooey speed loss just like when Goodra is being hit by a foe.

Reminds me of how Effect Monsters worked in Yugioh, back when you had to choose between a strong Normal Monster without an effect (in this case, a strong pokemon with a relatively boring ability/innate set) and an Effect Monster whose effect makes up for his lack of direct power (innates designed to make the pokemon interesting, maybe even strong). And because these Innates are designed for the Pokemon, things actually feel somewhat balanced. Sure, some effects used RNG like Barrel Dragon but that was rare.

I have never actually used a Rattata on my team before. Except when I was 9 and I'd catch shitmons to use as decoys sent out to die when item-healing my Vaporeon and Charizard and Kadabra. But this game makes me want to experiment with gimmicky underpowered shitmons that could finally help my team or serve a useful niche besides "Well SOMEBODY needs to use HMs" or "Guess somebody has to be my Flying type until I can catch the one I want".

>>52994345
I have no clue if there's a more reliable way but from what I've found, copypasting specific variations of autotiles seemingly requires you to do the manual box selection and copy paste the tiles to wherever you need them. unfortunately bringing them to separate layers will require you to copypaste from something that has said tile on the same layer
but if you're trying to copypaste stuff onto other maps you'll have to do an entire process because for some reason the program clears the clipboard when you move over to different maps
>open a separate project that isn't the one you're currently working with
>paste the selected tiles onto whatever map is open in the second project
>do NOT deselect
>move back to the main project window
>switch maps to whatever you're trying to paste things to
>move back to project #2, making sure whatever you pasted is still selected
>copy
>move back to main project
>paste

rmxp is otherwise decently intuitive so I have no clue how they shat the bed so hard in this specific aspect

I think the Pawmi line maybe has more to do with the shonen hero thing like people have suggested. Yes it has the defibrillator hands, but The concept of revival blessing to me always felt more like reviving a party member in Final fantasy or when an anime character saves their buddy with some crazy emotional act. Fighting type is definitely less well defined than it used to be, but I think as time goes on they're going to have to expand what can fit into each type's category. Fighting wasn't always going to be able to be martial artist Pokémon and stuff like that. Eventually it had to become Pokémon that are heroic/agressive/beastial. It was the only way. But it's funny people complain about that, yet nobody talks about how Normal type feels like it's being phased out of existence or how Ghost type has become more about "spiritual powers" and less about actual ghosts.

>>53000668
>>53000789
I figure Flamigo would be more based upon a secretary bird in terms of an animal focused on kicks, rather than crane style simply being about being a bird.
Ever since Mankey, the fighting type has been able to include things similar to relatively normal real-life animals, simply via the implication that they could use something more akin to kicking, punching, or brawling. There's still plenty of room for designs like that.

I do think that the typing has gotten more vague recently though, and designs like Paldean Tauros and Great Tusk blend the line between Fighting being about any sort of technique and instead lean more towards the idea that something can be fighting type purely by just having a metric ton of muscle.
Heracross is the earliest design I can think of that had a similar justification for being Fighting type, where it seems to be based on the idea of beetles fighting and how they'll throw enemies, but Heracross does have a relatively humanoid body type that still lends itself towards punching and kicking.

If merely being big and ferocious is enough to be Fighting type, then it raises the question of why mons like Rampardos, Slaking, Regigigas, or Darmanitan aren't fighting types. Why Bewear and not Ursaring or Beartic, who have higher base attack? It sets a bad trend to rely too much on the fact that moves like Close Combat or Body Press are Fighting moves that rely very little on a particular body type in order to justify any sort of body type being used.

>>52993796
Yeah admittedly in all my drafts and plans for writing with Latias, I always conceived of things being difficult and a bit sad for her after her brother died. Leading to issues that eventually need Ash to return to be solved (or something to that effect).
I'm going to use this excuse to ramble about my current writing

My current draft has Latias trying to fill the same role as her brother (quiet, distant protector, who remains overly careful in protecting not only the city but the secret of her existence). Of course, this approach doesn't work for her in the slightest. Latias is an outgoing, social animal, she can't handle the monotony of just patrolling the city, and most of all, she needs friends (which is even harder with Bianca out of Alto Mare so often nowadays for school). The obvious answer is that Latias needs to "move out". Nothing ever happens in Alto Mare that needs her, so it's not like her job of guardian is really holding her down. Yet, she's too scared of the possibility of something happening she can't even consider it. Bianca notices this of course, she knows Latias leaving would be best for her, but after losing Latios she can't handle the idea of losing Latias too. So she doesn't say anything.
That's the status quo until Ash comes back, just for a visit, and both Latias and Bianca realize the best path forward is a difficult one: Latias going on an adventure with Ash. To grow stronger, lose her fear of capture or harm, and finally grow into the person she's meant to be.

/vp/ tourist just passing through now that the Ashnime is finally ending, just wanted to say I'm unironically glad to see this thread and you degenerates are somehow still around and doing well and that I'm happy for you all.

I haven't been a hardcore Pokemon fan for the last 15 years or so, but I still remember finding the little dragon girl from the movie adorable and lavishing affection on her during postgame content in Emerald/Mystery Dungeon like it was yesterday.
Seeing you all still chugging on and staying loyal to your dragonwife for all this time and celebrating her reappearance just warms the heart. Perhaps it makes Gen 3 and its nostalgia not feel so long ago after all, or perhaps it just makes all those years seem like both a good time and a long time, if you all are still around.
And I'm always glad to see my fellow degenerates get their rare desert oasis of pandering to their niche ship or waifu in any series.

Thanks for reading my blog, and I hope you planefuckers win or at least get upgraded to main traveling partner/feMC levels by the end of Ash's last huzzah. Godspeed, you glorious motherfuckers.

>>52994428
Thanks a lot friend! Latias was my first ever crush when I was a kid. Having to manually catch her without the master ball I promptly used on some random legendary was quite the challenge. By this point she was easily my favorite mon and I still recall running around in Hoenn doing battles and entering her for the contests. Then some time later YouTube was created and I started finding M05 clips and I immediately fell in deep love with this cute shape-shifting dragon bird plane. Since then she has been living rent-free in my head as my one and only waifu and I have been using her in every pokémon game that I have owned. That same Latias now lives in Alpha Sapphire after traveling with me through all the games leading up to the the same region it all started.

It feels... weird. I am 27 years now and I have never been dissatisfied with how things turned out. I am fully self aware that all of this is fucking weird and I haven't really told anyone how I really feel besides two close friends of mine. I am neither socially nor physically weird and I work at a well-paying job. Literally nobody would suspect that over half of my live I have been in love with a fictional creature. I just don't want to let go of her as I genuinely love her. Sorry for the ramblings, I think I just wanted to get things off my chest to a community that might appreciate it. These threads have been great to find other like-minded people and I am happy to see I am not alone. I want to thank all of you for contributing!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52994663
Same case for me, except with a different Pokemon.
I'm 23, and work a blue collar trade. One of the "manly" ones. I'm not of the impression that I look, speak or act like a weirdo.
In fact, I make an active point of hiding my power level, feigning semi-ignorance when friends or workmates bring up most video game or internet things. To be fair, I'm not all that interested in them, I rarely game, and /vp/ is the only 4chan board I frequent. Make that social media site as a whole (Unless you count youtube).
You'd think I'm a true blue aussie cobber, mullet and all.
And yet, since watching M13, and that one zoroark episode of B/W, my mind has been broken by that rusefox.
It's sorta hard to explain, see. I must of been 11 at the time, maybe. I just saw her and something... clicked.
It isn't even purely horny, hell I'd argue it mostly isn't. I been doing that nofap thing for 6 months, and still dream of her, and falling asleep beneath that luxurious fur, or just something little like watching a movie together or enjoying a meal.
I'm not an imaginative fellow, but with her, I can vividly imagine the play of her fur in my fingers, her heartbeat against mine, y'know, that sorta thing.
I'm all too aware its weird.
Real bloody weird.
I'm sure Freud would have something or other to say about it (Funnily I've got a great relationship with both parents, so not that).
But there are bugger all nice sheilas in my town, so why not, eh?
Anyway, thats my rant for the month. Always nice knowing you aren't alone in being a bit of a loon.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52976348
>They don't punish the opponent, they protect you.
Yeah, too much. It makes switching with such bulky Pokemon too easy and makes pivoting too oppressive. If you actually played the Gen 8 Meta, you'd know how oppressive Teleport+Future Sight was, and that was enabled with the help of HDB. Even without that, slow turning into an extremely threatening Pokemon held back by its frailty is oppressive. It's why you saw a bunch of Slowbro+Weavile pairings, aside from the previously mentioned FuturePort tech, but you still also say Blissey+Weavile, Fini+Weavile, and DragaZera+Weavile, and then also saw tons of Melmetal as that shit was the only thing that could reliably beat Pivot+Weavile.
And also keep in mind, tons of things lost Knock Off in Gen 9 due to transfers replacing your moveset with level up moves. So if Gholdengo were to be banned, HDBs would make any attempts to hazard stack pointless in a game where without Gholdengo it's really hard to keep hazards up.
>Gho actively punishes you for merely existing.
How exactly does Gholdengo do this? And even if your exaggerated claims were true, Gholdengo's presence is still definitely a positive one because it's the only respite against the anti-hazards creep. It's much more welcoming than pivots being completely immune to their main form of counterplay and biggest limiter.
>A defensive item is never oppressive by definition.
Not only is this just straight up false, as defensive teams can absolutely be oppressive, but it also implies that only defensive teams or even defensive Pokemon use HDBs.Again, if you actually played the game, you'd know that NEARLY EVERYTHING uses fucking HDBs. Obviously lots of slow walls used this item, as well as Stealth Rock weak Pokemon, but anything that was going to switch around often used it. Tapu Koko, Dragapult, Zeraora, ect. It was so common that between all the Pokemon that use HDBs, Leftovers only beats it by 1 Pokemon, and this also includes CAPmons and NatDex meta too.

I think Chien-Pao, Dragonite, Espathra, Roaring Moon, and Dondozo could very well find themselves being banned before the HOME update drops. With Annihilape, Cyclizar, and Chi-Yu gone, they're stronger than ever. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53000531

It will work as long as the shield isn't up.

I think Garchomp/Gastrodon most likely be fantastic here. They've not made a habit of kitting out the 'mons with ridiculous coverage so far, so if Gren doesn't get an Ice or Grass move, they'll both be fine against Water and Dark as well as resist Poison. Those 3 move types are nearly guaranteed. The main difficulty here comes from guessing whether they go Mixed, Physical, or Special.

Physical has the only boosting option with Swords Dance, but Mixed or Special could easily use Taunt and Double Team to still be a tough fight. Either way, Clear Smog and a faster Taunt (probably Prankster only at that point) may be invaluable against it.

Honestly, though, I'm betting on Special or at least mixed. 7 Stars have been decently themed so far, with Charizard only getting fire and dragon attacks, and Cinderace getting "football attacks". I think its moveset will probably have Water Shuriken in it due to that. Probably Extrasensory, too, with its ninja association in Pokémon. If it's mixed it's probably getting Gunk Shot and Night Slash to go with it, probably, and if it's special it'll be going Tera Blast and Dark Pulse. Still tough to counter type wise. If it has Extrasensory, Water Absorb Clodsire won't even be safe.

Gastrodon and Garchomp are the safest bets here IMO with some Klefki/Tinkaton supports? Or Klefki Stored Power memes, I guess

>>52986103
To my knowledge, the only legitimate source of Beast Balls is for completing the Pokédex, and a small chance for winning the Academy Ace tournament.
Auction house only has the Apricorn Balls + Dream Ball.

Like I mentioned, I've stayed on v1.0.1 to facilitate the item duping glitch. It's a little time consuming, but my Violet save now has a stack of 999 Beast Balls, and I've got some 50+ on my Scarlet save.
Violet is my primary game which I'm going to update to v1.1 this weekend so I can do the Cinderace tera raid.
I'm currently stockpiling hard to get items before I do the update. I want lots of ability patches, Apricorn Balls, Master Balls, Bottle Caps, etc.

Cloning one ability patch can be sold for 125,000. That lets you buy 6 Bottle Caps, 12 Vitamins, etc, so it's faster than cloning those items individually.
Cash caps at 9,999,999 though.

>>52986682
I'm thinking the Hisui Pokémon will be a situation like Alola and Galar region.
>Import Raichu to Alola
>Breed Pichu from the Raichu
>Pichu evolves into Pikachu, then Alolan Raichu

Scyther, Ursaring, Stantler, Rufflet, may lack the means to evolve into their Hisuian formes, though Scyther and Ursaring are item based.
Dartrix, Dewott, and Cyndaquil may only evolve into their original final stages.

Stuff that is Hisuian in their base form like Voltorb, Sneasel, Growlithe, Qwilfish, will probably breedable and able to evolve as normal.
Hisuian Basculin has the recoil damage requirement in evolution, but probably won't be an issue.

If Stantler is able to evolve into Wyrdeer, the Psyshield Bash requirement wouldn't be an issue if the move can be learned via breeding/mirror herb.
Primeape evolves by using Rage Fist 20 times, after all.

An update is likely able to add in the items and moves necessary for some of the evolution requirements, but the region requirement could potentially be "cheated" by Area Zero doing hax, or a special area in the speculated North-East DLC portion of the map.

>>52990749
Well dunno about a guide but basically
>research what outbreak you want
https://www.serebii.net/scarletviolet/massoutbreaks.shtml
>open map, check for it, if it's not there then go to system options, hover the day/hours/minutes and press ok

This will reset every raid/outbreak as its technically a new day

>Do this until you find the one you want
>Once you do that, go and auto battle until you get the message "there's not many of x pokemon left"
>Then save and start a picnic, make a sandwich for encounter 3, sparkling 3, title 3

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1Krmy76O7u4ZHG-QySfmNa-85UHwDnvJIldfOhr-cxRs/htmlview#
or whatever guide you want


>Run in and out, respawn the pokemon, check for the shiny


If there's none, restart, you saved before the sandwich making so your herbas will be safe

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52998913
Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant are the hardest to catch, with catch rate 10.

The others are more reasonable with 50 or 30.
Scream Tail, Brute Bonnet, Iron Bundle, Iron Hands, are catch rate 50.
Great Tusk, Flutter Mane, Slither Wing, Sandy Shocks, Iron Treads, Iron Moth, Iron Thorn, Iron Jugulis, are catch rate 30.

It's been a goal to catch all of them in beast balls, and I want to get them all shiny in beast balls eventually, so I've been developing strategies.

Flutter Mane can't be false swiped, unless you trick a Ring Target onto it. Level 56+ encounters don't have Wish.
Both Iron Hands and Iron Thorns risks recoil damage through Wild Charge, but a typical Spore Breloom with a ground tera type should do the trick. Level 55 and below don't have Wild Charge, and ground tera type also ignores sandstorm damage.
Brute Bonnet can't be spored, and Thrash can potentially lead to confusion self-KO. Paralyze it with Thunder Wave then switch to Ceruledge and False Swipe

That's about the extent of difficulty with them, none of the others carry self-KO risks.
Some of them can hit pretty hard, particularly Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant, but the Poison Heal + Spore Breloom at level 100 and activating Rock tera typing can survive most of it through toxic orb self-heal and persistent sporing.

It's a character design thing. A Zoroark's ponytail, particularly the part after the bead, is in the same place you'd find a fox tail if it was attached to their keester. They were trying to be clever and weird. Hisuian Zoroark, being ghosty, ended up with a different look for its hair, but still needed some sort of tail to look complete. So they gave it a real, if rather stubby stand in.

In the official Diamond and Pearl series of the Pokémon Anime, Cynthia would often be seen having an ice cream. My way is best
>Items in battle are fine but I only buy super potions and full heals so it's not even very good to use them by the end game.
>Held items and other such things are obviously fine
>Use starter all the way through, catch 5 other mons by the mid way point, then catch 3-6 other mons in the latter half of the game. Shuffle all dudes around equally.
>Overlapping types are fine as long as weaknesses aren't shared.
>Battle all the trainers and faint every wild mon I run into. Only use repels if truly necessary like on water routes.
>Allow myself to skip parts that I have no reason to want, like grabbing a TM I can't use, but otherwise do everything
>Battle gyms as soon as I can, and if I lose then I do at least one other things, like explore an adjacent area, before challenging it again. I also don't SE and take the L like a man
>Overall try to interact with all the content and get the most use out of every feature. For example I never finish a gen 2 playthrough without rigorously doing the daily events along the way, I never do a gen 3 or 4 playthrough without growing berries, making poffins/pokeblocks and doing the contests, etc. I just like to get the most out my games
>Teach TMs as soon as or shortly after I get them, even if they're finite. They're made to be used, and it adds a lot to the enjoyability of the game
>Never use HM slaves and if I do I release them as soon as I can

posts.com:
I just beat Red in crystal and it was a fucking BATTLE.
I was grinding up my team of Feraligatr, Gengar, Slowking, Umbreon and Snorlax and was going to use an onix I got from Mt. Silver for his Pikachu.
I lost Snorlax while grinding the elite four at level 59! Disaster!
So I got pissed and decided to use my rare candies and just fight Red. Fuck it. Just fuck it.
Final team was:
Bepis the Feraligatr lv 62
Mr. Knox the Slowking lv 62
Tsushima the Gengar lv 64
Enoch the Umbreon lv 62
Gibraltar the Onix lv 48
a random electrode from rocket hideout that I sacked to Charizard during the fight.

Onix trolled pikachu to death in like 30 turns lol
I let it die to Espeon then Umbreon obviously came in and walled for days
He sends in Snorlax. I try to toxic/confuse ray troll it for a bit and he uses rest, it didn't work out so I went into Gengar.
Mean look then curse, two moves I'd had to keep on him since the very beginning and it finally paid off and I killed the fatass.
Red sends Venusaur to be 2HKO'd by my Gengar's psychic.
Then Charizard comes out.....with sun up already.
I sack Electrode, go into Feraligatr and unfortunately lose him to a crit flamethrower +fire spin chip, but gengar is able to come in and pick him off with thunder punch.
Finally, blastoise. I go for curse yet again (I had leftovers equipped so I got back to full on snorlax), and then go into Slowking to sit on him for a couple more turns.

Only Slowking and Gengar survived the end, but it was an epic battle.

On to the next. I'm thinking possibly Red/Fire Red or....something else. Give suggestions please! This was a really fun nuzlocke aside from a lot of grinding. Gengar was the MVP the whole run pretty much. 40 hours of playtime!

grass types are sadly very shit in Johto. There are some random trainer battles where of course it'll be useful to have a grass type, but all of the main battles shit all over grass types. Every single one. There are no favorable matchups, only semi-okay matchups. The one exception I can think of it Chuck's Poliwrath being water type. But electric does it better + is useful vs more fights.
Hoppip is not bad though, he has speed and great utility moves and can absolutely troll anything in the game to death with sleep powder and leech seed. Great team support if you have a setup pokemon with a boosting move or something that would benefit from being in against a sleeping opponent (pretty much anything).
He is a chore to train, but I find him fun to use.
Just know if you use a grass type, its an uphill battle.

First game of gen 3 is done
I was a bit worried during midgame as my team wasn't feeling so hot, but an Abra in Granite Tunnel helped carry me into a better setup later on. Camerupt is way more solid than I thought, and Sceptile starts doing damage once Leaf Blade comes in

Every fight in E4 was a sweeping breeze. Glacia was funny as Glalie is such a shit mon that its pathetic Crunches didn't stop Alakazam from setting up and wrecking her team

I thought I could do the same to Drake as Shelgon is very weak, but Alakazam got two Speed reductions from Rock Tomb, and only survived vs the upcoming Flygon because it decided to Sand Attack instead of killing me, so I had to dance a bit, including a risky Masquerain switch in vs Salamence's Fly. He gladly survived and Ice Beam'd the dragon for the win

I decided to put my profane crab creation against Steven, thinking I could at least take down a few mons, so I strapped her with a Pecha Berry and started dancing on Skarmory, who missed a Toxic, set up Spikes and hit Toxic, then promptly got Brick Broken, letting Old Bay go berserk on Steven's team, distributing Returns and Brick Breaks without a shred of mercy

I hadn't played Gen 3 in ages, and it's better than I remember, but the whole "too much water" thing is a bit real during late game. Onwards onto Sapphire now

What do you guys think of this variant I just sketched up? Gonna start a daily variant on my Twitter and figured the best #1 was #1. This is not for a fangame or anything in particular, just for fun and a daily opportunity to improve my abilities.
>"Red" Bulbasaur
>Pure Poison Type
>"Lazier but more aggressive and defensive, this mischievous mutation of Bulbasaur is too toxic to sustain any plant life. When threatened, the large poisonous bulb on its back emits a volatile gas that causes those approaching to sob with burning eyes."
>the 4 colors of its palette are the 4 onion colors: white, yellow, green, and purple (red)
>bigger fangs, shady eyes, and the triangle scales swapped for circles to evoke the bubble shape that has become synonymous with Poison type in recent generations
So, what do you think? I know the actual quality of the art isn't amazing but that's why I'm starting a daily practice. What would you change about it? What do you like about it?

Also, post suggestions for other variants, I love the variant concept and seeing what everyone else comes up with.

It might be doable on an unmodded copy, but I think it would be tricky.

>>52998951
someone once mentioned the line was also inspired by japanese delinquents. Like Timburr for example looks like a 70's Yanki, hence the Pompadour hairstyle. Most Yanki were school dropouts that ended up doing informal work, so it was common to see them working at construction sites back in the 70s and 80s.
Gurdurr's weird afro is also meant to be a Punch perm, a hairstyle often used by delinquents and construction workers.

Once again the DLC is called Magenta Mirage I forgot to include a few things in my last post!

New Forms for Existing Pokémon
3 New Vivillon patterns
Ultra Violet Pattern (Looks sort of like space)
Deep Scarlet Pattern (Looks like a scarlet savannah)
Magical Magenta Pattern (Looks like a Magenta field of flowers)
Regional Forms
Seel - Dewgong - Seanetel Ice/Steel
Sentret - Heret Flying/Fighting (Based on the Suger glider and superheroes)
Miltank Grass/Fairy

Regional Fake based on Snorlax Fighting/Dark

Paradox Forms
Paradox Ninetales: Iron Climate Fire/Ice
Paradox Exploud: Iron Speaker Normal/Steel
Paradox Mega Audino: Archaic Doctor Fairy/Poison
Paradox Gliscor Ground/Poison

Lusamine also returns (She now uses Nihilego and her new ace Pheromosa)

Light of Ruin is learned by all of the Aura Trio as well as AZ's floette

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53002437
Pokestars is actually pretty neat for essentially being puzzles using Pokemon's battle mechanics. It's been a while, but some I remember are defeating a Ghost/Dark Wonder Guard mon, aiming to lose against a Sewaddle with Endure and Endeavor, and stalling out a battle which is determined by choosing the correct dialogue choice (your giant girlfriend will spam Teeter Dance if you say you'll still be with her despite her new size, and Double Slap if you show hesitation. Yes, that's the plot). It's in the same vain as the battle simulations from the Orre games.

Ironically I think the reason the tutorial was so abhorrently long and disruptive was because they had legitimately put so much work into it and they really wanted to shove it in your face so you didn't pass by it without knowing it existed. There's over 10 movie series, each with 3-4 individual movies, and every single one of them has a good, bad, and secret ending depending on if it expects you to win/lose/stall. Not to mention all the custom sprites and cut-ins for both protagonists, enemy trainers, and completely unique "pokemon". It reads to me something they really didn't want players to just miss, but that tutorial was the absolute worst way to go about it. It's been a long time since I completed it though, so maybe there's a ton of shit or baby easy puzzles I don't remember. My memory is just being pleasantly surprised when I actually went back and did it.
